Award.AwardTitle: The 14th U.S.-Korea Forum on Nanotechnology: Internet of Things Including Nanosensors and Neuromorphic Computing, To Be Held September, 11-12, 2017, in Washington, DC

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed project for a Forum seeks financial support for scientists and engineers in the nanotechnology area with an objective to recommend new paradigms in this area and promote collaborative initiatives between the US and Korea, two countries. The "14th U.S.-Korea Forum on Nanotechnology: Internet of Things (IoT) including Nanosensors and Neuromorphic Computing" will host 8 senior presenters and 8 additional early-career presenters (underrepresented minorities will be strongly encouraged) and an approximately equal number of Korean presenters. It will actively encourage partnerships in nanotechnology for breakthroughs in various topics in IoT including nanosensors as well as novel computing architecture in information technology, in addition to strengthening achievements and assessing the progress on recommendations made during the previous meetings of this type.
The Forum will play a key role in identifying new directions for research on IoT technologies and neuromorphic computing addressing long-term challenges in nanotechnological fundamentals and its application for the mutual benefit of both the US and Korea. The meeting proceedings and findings will be published in a booklet form by the National Nanotechnology Policy Center, Korea and on Carnegie Mellon?s website, which will be available to a broader public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcome Report:

The 14th US-Korea Forum on Nanotechnology:

Internet of Things (IoT) including nanosensors

and neuromorphic computing

PI: Myung S. Jhon, Carnegie Mellon

co-PI: Elias Towe, Carnegie Mellon

Ahmed Busnaina, Northeastern University

Mamadou Diallo, California Institute of Technology

 

We organized the 14th nanotechnology Forum between the US and Korea, to explore the topics on Internet of Things (IoT) including nanosensors and neuromorphic computing, on September 11th & 12th, 2017 in Falls Church, VA, USA. The delegates at the 5th meeting of the US-Korea Joint Committee on Scientific and Technological Cooperation (held on October 30th & 31st, 2002 in Seoul, Korea) agreed that the establishment of a US-Korea Forum on Nanotechnology would be beneficial to enhance research collaboration in the field of nanotechnology among scientists and engineers from both countries. With this mission, we established the 1st US-Korea Forum on nanotechnology, via National Science Foundation (NSF) funding, on October 14th -18th of 2003, in Seoul and continued for the past thirteen years. Participation was also overseen and funded by the Korea Ministry of Science and ICT, which is the Korean counterpart to NSF.

During this Forum, we further empowered a common platform for scientists and engineers from both countries to accommodate urgent technology contribution on nanosensors for IoT devices and neuromorphic computing. Ten senior oral presenters and eight additional junior poster presenters from US as well as eight senior oral presenters and five additional junior poster presenters from Korea participated. Please refer to our website for further details (http://www.cmu.edu/nanotechnology-forum/Forum_14GeneralInfo.htm.) We actively encouraged research collaborations by identifying topics and collaborative teams and partnership in the field of nanotechnology convergence to generate massive impact in nanoscience to strengthening achievements and assessing the progress based on our Forum’s recommendations. We aimed to provide maximum opportunities to young scientists, including the graduate students as well as encouraging participation from diverse group.

The Intellectual Merits include:

(i)    Providing a common platform for bi-national community of expert researchers and innovators who are working on the leading edge of neuromorphic computing and IoT including nanosensors, and

(ii)   Simulating efforts to promote the above two areas for the next generation by fully utilizing nanotechnology convergence and biomimetric methods. The outcome for these timely technologies leads to the establishment of milestone for the nanotechnology convergence.

The Broader Impacts include:

(i)    Bringing new paradigms in these fields and promoted collaborative initiatives between the two countries as well as constructed policy roadmap,

(ii)   Contributing to society, the global environment and economy in a broader sense by focusing on timely emerging technologies critical to the 4th industrial revolution,

(iii) Promoting the exchange of researchers between the two countries, especially strongly encouraging the collaboration among young scientists, including graduate students in contrast to the previous forums, and

(iv)  Initiating potential collaborative interactions among companies as well as memorandum of understanding between US and Korea.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/20/2018
Modified by: Myung S Jhon
